title: Add git.showCommitInput config option (#79074)
body:
Adds feature requested in #79074.

To implement this, I mostly followed the pattern for the 'git.branchSortOrder' option and used VS Code's SourceControl API to toggle visibility of the input box.

title: Support font transparency in minimap

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
I don't know how feasible this is, but it would be great if the minimap used the same font transparency as the editor.

For instance:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15098499/66222386-a9d06300-e696-11e9-9f52-71c0fd7fe474.png)
corresponds to 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15098499/66222406-b48af800-e696-11e9-9c13-6f2821d6adf6.png)

It gets very confusing when you have a lot of comments.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15098499/66222541-029ffb80-e697-11e9-9b59-d96362a4a836.png)

I'm sure you can tell the bottom right block are comments. But did you know the top block also are?

Yes, I know, I could pick a color that more closely resembles the grey I'm after without using transparency. And that works out great. But from a theme creators perspective, not being able to use font transparency really cuts down on your ability to easily tweak things and make scalable systems of color.

title: Hovering the glyph margin makes editor jump-scroll with editor.cursorSurroundingLines
body:
This happens in the current Insiders v1.39.0

- VSCode Version: 1.39.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.14.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set `"editor.cursorSurroundingLines": 5`
2. Open your settings.json file (`cmd+,`)
3. Hover the glyph margin
4. Notice that the editor scroll jumps to make the line you hovered stay within the surrounding lines.

[Demo](https://gph.is/g/Z2V2ObD)

Expectation:
The editor scroll doesn't move while you're hovering the glyph margin.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled? Yes

title: Intellisense for launch.json

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Issue Type: Feature Request When creating new configurations for launching Python, entering "cwd": provides just one intellisense option; the default value: "${workspaceFolder}" The comment at the top of the file says "Use IntelliSense to learn about possible attributes. Hover to view descriptions of existing attributes." The question is, how is anyone supposed to find ${fileDirname} when there is no intellisense for it or any other keyword attribute applicable to "cwd:"? I always have to spend time looking up these keywords online. If users are forced to set edit a JSON file in order to set their debug options, then the intellisense should at least be comprehensive. Thank you VS Code version: Code 1.38.1 (b37e54c98e1a74ba89e03073e5a3761284e3ffb0, 2019-09-11T13:35:15.005Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17763

title: Disable all extensions and allow to enable selectively
body:
I cannot check for an issue in extension because I need to disable all except that target extension. Option `--disable-extensions` allow us to disable all extensions at once but it doesn't allow to enable specific extensions
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18731681/66200822-3570e080-e6e5-11e9-9ae5-8cd2749213d2.png)
Or it should be `--disable-extensions-except ID1 ID2 ID3`
I don't know which one is the best

title: Replace dialog doesn't fully go away if contains multiple lines
body: Issue Type: Bug Steps to reproduce: 1. Open replace dialog box ("Edit-Replace" or Ctrl+H) 2. Select "replace with" input box (bottommost) 3. Type in several words, separated with Ctrl+Enter or Shift+Enter 4. Close dialog (Esc) Actual result: dialog moves up but part of the dialog remains visible Extected result: dialog moves up and fully hides itself ![Screenshot_3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10653234/66198419-96d58700-e6c6-11e9-8c4f-6fda9ebfa3fb.png) ![Screenshot_4](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10653234/66198431-9d63fe80-e6c6-11e9-8700-4de4518236b1.png) VS Code version: Code 1.38.1 (b37e54c98e1a74ba89e03073e5a3761284e3ffb0, 2019-09-11T13:35:15.005Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 6.1.7601

title: argument quoting in launch.json

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
In task.json it is possible to [specify the quoting of the argument](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/tasks#_custom-tasks).

```
  "args": [
    {
      "value": "folder with spaces",
      "quoting": "escape"
    }
  ]
```

In launch.json this is not accepted.

Quoting is done automatic if the argument contains a space but I want to control it the same as in task.json because my argument does not contain a space but needs to be quoted or escaped.

title: SASS Modules (@forward and @use)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Dart Sass 1.23.0 dropped recently and with it, [a new module system](http://sass.logdown.com/posts/7858341-the-module-system-is-launched).
It would be great if this was added into the language features for SCSS/SASS.

Documentation pages for each of the new at-rules:

- [@use](https://sass-lang.com/documentation/at-rules/use)
- [@forward](https://sass-lang.com/documentation/at-rules/forward)

title: editor.cursorSurroundingLines selection should respect drag direction
body:
This happens in the current Insiders v1.39.0

- VSCode Version: 1.39.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.14.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set `"editor.cursorSurroundingLines": 5`
2. Click anywhere within the lower scroll off zone and slowly drag up
3. Notice that your selection went down

or

2. Click anywhere within the upper scroll off zone and slowly drag down
3. Notice that your selection went up

[Demo](https://gph.is/g/4wPyG12)

Expectation:
When clicking the lower scroll off zone, the editor window should only scroll down if your selection moves down and when clicking the upper scroll off zone, the editor window should only scroll up if your selection moves up.

Recommendation:
Completely disable the scroll off zone while clicking or dragging and let the editor behave as if `"editor.cursorSurroundingLines": 0` and re-enable it on mouse up.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled? Yes

title: editor.tokenColorCustomizations comments does not modify comment punctuation
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.38.1
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 6.3.9600

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Modify "comments" in "editor.tokenColorCustomizations"
2. Note how comment punctionation (i.e. `//` or `/* */`) are not highlighted

For instance,
```json
"editor.tokenColorCustomizations": {
     "[Material Theme Darker High Contrast]": {
         "comments": "#f00"
     }
}
```
produces
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15098499/66341295-91697e00-e90c-11e9-8c02-911c309f2388.png)

I was able to target comment punctuation via the TextMate rule `punctuation.definition.comment`

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Consider using TS project references for smoke and automation projects
Improved logging for file rename event
body: When a file is moved to a different folder, an RENAMED event is generated. The property `newDirectory` is correctly used to generate the `IDiskFileChange` but not for logging.

title: Problem with selection on tooltip
body: Issue Type: Feature Request When hovering over something that produces a tooltip, one might want to copy a portion of the text in the tooltip box. With my mousepointer I start selecting that bit of text, but as soon as my pointer leaves the tooltip area (while mousebutton still pressed) the tooltip box disappears, making me unable to copy the desired text. [![Image from Gyazo](https://i.gyazo.com/25d2d43bc4d5620a65bd8a271267c99b.gif)](https://gyazo.com/25d2d43bc4d5620a65bd8a271267c99b) Desired behavior: While in the "selecting" action (mousebutton still pressed) the tooltip should not disappear. VS Code version: Code 1.38.1 (b37e54c98e1a74ba89e03073e5a3761284e3ffb0, 2019-09-11T13:35:15.005Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17134

title: onDidChangeTextDocument called when closing an unsaved document.
body:
onDidChangeTextDocument() is fired when you make changes in a document.  The event is also fired when you do not save the document and close it even through you made no further changes.   There are a number of issues with this behavior.

1.  The event for the same change should not fire twice. When closing the document, it has not changed since the last event call. 
2. The range included with the TextDocumentChangeEvent parameter is incorrect.  For example if I type a single character on line 12, the change range spans from line 12, position 0 to line 13, position 0.  
3,. There is no way to determine why the method is called. (See issue #36939).   

My extension may modify the document in response to user input. It depends on the region where the document is modified.  The second problem triggers my extension to modify the unsaved document when the user closes it.  This is turn triggers the document to be reopened.

title: Renaming a file doesn't update imports and shows "(deleted)"
body:
This only happens in current Insiders build v1.39.0

- VSCode Version: 1.39.0 (Insiders)
- OS Version: macOS 10.14.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set `"javascript.updateImportsOnFileMove.enabled": "prompt"`
2. Rename a JS file that has an import statement somewhere (prompt will trigger)
3. Rename it back to original name
4. Observe that the prompt does not trigger (and the import statement does not update) and that now you have a "`(deleted)`" in front of your file name in the editor ([screenshot](https://imgur.com/8VZ85Ie)).

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?
Yes

title: javascript.suggest.names doesn't work if javascript.implicitProjectConfig.checkJs is enabled
body:
This issue also happens in Insiders v1.39.0

- VSCode Version: 1.39.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.14.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set `"javascript.suggest.names": true`
2. Set `"javascript.implicitProjectConfig.checkJs": true`
3. Notice that word based suggestions (in JS files) does not work
4. Set `"javascript.implicitProjectConfig.checkJs": false`
5. Notice that word based suggestions (in JS files) now work

Expectation:
Type checking (`javascript.implicitProjectConfig.checkJs`) should not have anything to do with word based suggestions (`javascript.suggest.names`).

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?
Yes

title: wrong HSL to RGB conversion when using the color picker
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3831
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.17763

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create an hsl color attribute in a css file as such:     `color: hsl(231, 6%, 24%);`
2. Use Color picker to convert it into rgb (by clicking the top panel of the color picker)
3. The result is `rgb(57, 58, 64);` which is incorrect, it should be `rgb(58, 59, 65);`

![vscode](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1499269/66129048-6d95f780-e5ef-11e9-8a18-a622cb05e000.gif)


Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

Each component (r, g and b) seems to be truncated rather than rounded after the HSL to RGBA calculation.

However, if I run the function  `HSLA.toRGBA` located in `src/vs/base/common/color.ts` then the result is correct, because each component are correctly rounded. Proof: https://repl.it/repls/FirsthandVirtualLanguage

title: [json] JSON formatter does not allow vertical alignment

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
```
Version: 1.38.1
Commit: b37e54c98e1a74ba89e03073e5a3761284e3ffb0
Date: 2019-09-11T13:30:08.229Z
Electron: 4.2.10
Chrome: 69.0.3497.128
Node.js: 10.11.0
V8: 6.9.427.31-electron.0
OS: Linux x64 5.2.14-200.fc30.x86_64
```
All whitespace formatting is lost:

* vertical value alignment
* value grouping (using an empty line)
* single item lists are expanded to multiple lines

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write a JSON file and whitespace align values:
```
{
    "foo": {
        "foo1":         "var1",
        "somelongname": "another value",
        
        "anothergroupofvariables":  "separated by an empty line",
        "key":                      "value",
        
        "singlelistitem": [ "oneitem" ]
    }
}
```
2. Format the document using `Ctrl + Shift + I`
```
{
    "foo": {
        "foo1": "var1",
        "somelongname": "another value",
        "anothergroupofvariables": "separated by an empty line",
        "key": "value",
        "singlelistitem": [
            "oneitem"
        ]
    }
}
```
<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

According to the RFC7159 JSON standard whitespace alignment is allowed: https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/pdfrfc/rfc7159.txt.pdf.

I'm reporting this here, since this is affecting the default JSON formatter. Please advise if I should report this elsewhere.

I agree whitespace alignment makes no sense for JSON strings generated and read mainly by machines, but for JSON strings written and maintained by humans, whitespace alignment is essential for good readability and quick object identification.

title: [Feature Request]Add option so [Auto Find In Selection] enable [Find In Selection] ONLY if selected text contains multiple lines
Disabling/Re-enabling image preview extension steals focus
body:
Testing https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/81674

Steps to reproduce:
* Open an image
* Open image preview extension page, disable and reload
* The image view tab has a loading indicator
* Switch to the extension page to enable it, but nothing is clickable
* Go back to the image tab and revisit the extension page fixes the issue

title: Two launch configurations with the same preLaunchTask trigger "already running" warning
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.38.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.14.6

Steps to Reproduce:

With the following .vscode/launch.json:
```json
{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "compounds": [
    {
      "name": "all",
      "configurations": ["web-server", "web-ui"]
    }
  ],
  "configurations": [
    {
      "name": "web-server",
      "type": "node",
      "request": "attach",
      "port": 20006,
      "restart": true,
      "preLaunchTask": "npm: dev-web"
    },
    {
      "name": "web-ui",
      "type": "chrome",
      "request": "launch",
      "url": "http://localhost:20005/",
      "timeout": 20000,
      "webRoot": "${workspaceFolder}/web",
      "preLaunchTask": "npm: dev-web"
    }
  ]
}
```

Launching the "all" configuration works properly, but presents the following:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41373/66068681-e66b5580-e502-11e9-8b90-531f18cb47c7.png)
